channel.title: Server Index and Player id
channel.description:
Hey
i was just wondering if player id is the same as server index. If not, could someone please tell me the differences? Thanks.

item.title: Server Index and Player id
item.dc:creator: @Vrunk Vrunk
item.description:
@Vrunk wrote:

adu:

Just out of curiosity, in rsc what does PId have to do with “catching”. I know that if the attacker has a lower pid than the defender, when the defender runs, the attackers attack-packet is handled first causing the “catch”. SO then how come sometimes a player with a higher Pid is able to “catch” a player with lower id?

If I remember correctly - for some reason the players running both North and East were always catchable, no matter the PID. It was when people started running South and West that the PID had to be lower than the other person. Southeast and Northwest were THE most difficult to catch (it was impossible to catch from 2 squares away). Northeast and Southwest you could catch from 2 squares away.

Read full topic

item.title: Server Index and Player id
item.dc:creator: @Stork Stork
item.description:
@Stork wrote:

In RSC, it seems like the events (packets from connected users) are processed in order of user index (player id) which seems stupid.

RSCD based servers processed events based on the order the event (packet) was received, which makes a lot more sense. That means the foo’ who clicks first, plays first.

Read full topic

item.title: Server Index and Player id
item.dc:creator: @system system
item.description:
@system wrote:

I think it is necessary anyway, as I think both the server-index and username-hash is used together to verify that the player you are trying to update are the same as previously initialized (in the client then I mean).

Read full topic

item.title: Server Index and Player id
item.dc:creator: @adu adu
item.description:
@adu wrote:

So what you guys are saying is that PID or server-index dosent really matter in private servers since the packet is handled in the order it waz recieved?

Read full topic

item.title: Server Index and Player id
item.dc:creator: @xEnt xEnt
item.description:
@xEnt wrote:

Back in RSC, i never understood why when i thieve a chest, and even the other person could thieve it just after me, but he would still get it because he had a lower pid, is because of that 600milisecond global timer? so if i were to thieve on say 0.1second and he got it on 0.5 second before the next loop, the server would still take his first because it takes lower PID’s first.

Read full topic

item.title: Server Index and Player id
item.dc:creator: @Peter Peeter
item.description:
@Peter wrote:

[quote=“ephemeral, post:5, topic:210742”]kingigor55: You’re wrong there… Server-index and the so called ‘PID’ are the same thing. When you login to the server, the server assigns your account by a number, which is the lowest number possible without taking any other currently logged in accounts number (server-index). This server-index is a unique number. Whenever someone logs out, their server-index is released for usage by any other account that logs in after they have logged out, and if there are no lower unique not-currently-used server-indices.

The server-index is what you send to the client when updating different things that involves other players for instance. It uses this server-index client-side to update the appropriate player-appearance, player-position etc.

I also think you are referring this with server-index that counts up for every login to be what is done in servers such as the very first FreeScape server, and eScape, aswell as early wL-based server-emulators?[/quote]

I do believe RSCDaemon v25 counts up also, although I might be mistaken. Although he’s right and I’m 100% sure on the fact that player-ID or “server-index”, however you wish to call it, it doesn’t matter for the player.

On RSC the lower your ID the “better” you were. All commands/packets were handled in the order of player ID, but on RSCD they’re handled in the order they come, so in other words - first come first serve.

Read full topic

item.title: Server Index and Player id
item.dc:creator: @system system
item.description:
@system wrote:

kingigor55: You’re wrong there… Server-index and the so called ‘PID’ are the same thing. When you login to the server, the server assigns your account by a number, which is the lowest number possible without taking any other currently logged in accounts number (server-index). This server-index is a unique number. Whenever someone logs out, their server-index is released for usage by any other account that logs in after they have logged out, and if there are no lower unique not-currently-used server-indices.

The server-index is what you send to the client when updating different things that involves other players for instance. It uses this server-index client-side to update the appropriate player-appearance, player-position etc.

I also think you are referring this with server-index that counts up for every login to be what is done in servers such as the very first FreeScape server, and eScape, aswell as early wL-based server-emulators?

Read full topic

item.title: Server Index and Player id
item.dc:creator: @kingigor55 kingigor55
item.description:
@kingigor55 wrote:

If you’re referring to PID back in RSC, with lower the better then no its not same. Server index keeps counting up each logout/login regardless of players online.

Read full topic

@system wrote:

Yes, they are both the same…
